title: 114_hr4463
content:
The "Brownfields Reauthorization Act of 2016" increases funding limits for direct remediation and introduces multipurpose Brownfields grants. The "Brownfields Reauthorization Act of 2016" introduces multipurpose brownfields grants for eligible entities to conduct various activities related to inventory, characterization, assessment, planning, or remediation. The Brownfields Reauthorization Act of 2016 offers grants up to $950,000 for activities at brownfield sites, with a limit of 15% of funds per fiscal year. Criteria for grant awards include the ability to provide an overall plan. The Brownfields Reauthorization Act of 2016 offers grants for revitalization of brownfield sites, with a requirement to demonstrate capacity and meet site needs. Recipients must spend the full grant amount within 3 years. The Brownfields Reauthorization Act of 2016 requires grant recipients to spend the full grant amount within 3 years, with a possibility of extension at the discretion of the Administrator. SEC. 4. EXPANDED ELIGIBILITY FOR NONPROFIT ORGANIZATIONS. Section 104(k)(1) of the Comprehensive Environmental Response, Compensation, and Liability Act of 1980 is amended to include eligibility criteria for nonprofit organizations, limited liability corporations, and limited partnerships. The eligibility criteria for nonprofit organizations, limited liability corporations, and limited partnerships under Section 104(k)(1) of the Comprehensive Environmental Response, Compensation, and Liability Act of 1980 include specific requirements such as being a qualified community development entity. SEC. 5. Allowing administrative costs for grant recipients. SEC. 5 allows for administrative costs for grant recipients under the Comprehensive Environmental Response, Compensation, and Liability Act of 1980. Amendments are made to paragraph (5) of section 104(k), including redesignating clauses and subclauses. An eligible entity can use up to 8 percent of grant or loan amounts for administrative costs, excluding investigation, response action design, and natural resource monitoring. SEC. 6. Treatment of certain publicly owned brownfield sites: An eligible governmental entity may receive a grant for property acquired before January 11, 2002, even if not a bona fide prospective purchaser, as long as they have not caused a release of hazardous substances. SEC. 7. Authorization of appropriations: Amend section 104(k)(12) of the Comprehensive Environmental Response, Compensation, and Liability Act of 1980 to authorize $250,000,000 for each fiscal year from 2016 to 2021. 

SEC. 8. State Response Program Funding: Amend section 128(a)(3) of the Act to update the funding year from 2006 to 2021.
